message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible meniscal tear. A palpable click is often associated with this injury, and the other options are more indicative of other knee injuries such as ACL tear (anterior displacement of the tibia) or collateral ligament tear (laxity to varus stress). Severe pain with compression of the patella is seen in patellofemoral pain syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical exam findings suggest a possible tear of the meniscus. A palpable click with passive motion of the knee is a common finding in meniscal tears. Anterior displacement of the tibia relative to the femur suggests ACL injury, laxity to varus stress suggests MCL injury, and severe pain with compression of the patella suggests patellofemoral syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of anabolic steroid use and physical exam findings suggest a possible ligamentous injury. A palpable click with passive motion of the knee is a classic finding in a tear of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). Anterior displacement of the tibia relative to the femur may indicate a tear of the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL). Laxity to varus stress may indicate a medial collateral ligament (MCL) or lateral collateral ligament (LCL) tear. Severe pain with compression of the patella may indicate a patellar fracture or patellar tendon injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only a palpable click with passive motion of the knee is indicative of a meniscal tear, which is a common injury in football players. Anterior displacement of the tibia and laxity to varus stress indicate ACL and MCL tear respectively, while severe pain with compression of the patella indicates patellofemoral syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of anabolic steroid use and physical exam findings suggest a possible ACL tear, specifically with a positive Lachman test which involves applying anterior tibial force while holding the femur in place. Option (A), a palpable click with passive motion of the knee, is a classic finding in ACL tears. Option (B) suggests a possible patellar or kneecap dislocation. Option (C) is associated with a lateral collateral ligament or LCL injury. Option (D) suggests possible patellofemoral pain syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a past medical history of anabolic steroid use, which increases the risk of ligamentous injuries. Valgus stress on the knee can detect medial collateral ligament injury, and a palpable click with passive motion of the knee is often seen in patients with meniscal tear. Anterior displacement of the tibia relative to the femur is seen in anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury, laxity to varus stress is seen in lateral collateral ligament injury, and severe pain with compression of the patella is seen in patellofemoral pain syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presentation is consistent with a meniscal tear, and the palpable click with passive motion of the knee is a classic physical exam finding for this condition. Anterior displacement of the tibia relative to the femur is seen in anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injuries, laxity to varus stress is seen in medial collateral ligament (MCL) injuries, and severe pain with compression of the patella is seen in patellofemoral syndrome. Arthrocentesis ruled out joint effusion as a cause of the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient complains of severe knee pain with possible ligamentous injury. Option A, a palpable click with passive motion of the knee, is suggestive of a meniscal injury. Anterior displacement of the tibia relative to the femur is suggestive of an ACL tear. Laxity to varus stress is suggestive of MCL or LCL injury. Severe pain with compression of the patella is suggestive of patellofemoral syndrome. Thus, the correct answer is A.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of anabolic steroid use, the mechanism of injury, and the physical exam findings suggest a possible ACL tear. A palpable click with passive motion of the knee is a classic sign of an ACL tear. Options B and C are indicative of collateral ligament injuries, while option D suggests patellofemoral syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of anabolic steroid use and physical examination findings suggest a possible tear of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). A palpable click with passive motion of the knee is a classic finding in an ACL tear, as the torn ligament can get caught in the joint and suddenly release. Anterior displacement of the tibia relative to the femur is a finding in a posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) tear, while laxity to varus stress is a finding in a medial collateral ligament (MCL) or lateral collateral ligament (LCL) tear. Severe pain with compression of the patella is a finding in patellofemoral pain syndrome.
